service: Amazon Kendra is a service for indexing large document sets.

operations.BatchDeleteDocument:
Removes one or more documents from an index. The documents must have been added with the BatchPutDocument operation.

The documents are deleted asynchronously. You can see the progress of the deletion by using AWS CloudWatch. Any error messages releated to the processing of the batch are sent to you CloudWatch log.
operations.BatchPutDocument:
Adds one or more documents to an index.

The BatchPutDocument operation enables you to ingest inline documents or a set of documents stored in an Amazon S3 bucket. Use this operation to ingest your text and unstructured text into an index, add custom attributes to the documents, and to attach an access control list to the documents added to the index.

The documents are indexed asynchronously. You can see the progress of the batch using AWS CloudWatch. Any error messages related to processing the batch are sent to your AWS CloudWatch log.
operations.CreateDataSource:
Creates a data source that you use to with an Amazon Kendra index.

You specify a name, connector type and description for your data source. You can choose between an S3 connector, a SharePoint Online connector, and a database connector.

You also specify configuration information such as document metadata (author, source URI, and so on) and user context information.

CreateDataSource is a synchronous operation. The operation returns 200 if the data source was successfully created. Otherwise, an exception is raised.
operations.CreateFaq: Creates an new set of frequently asked question (FAQ) questions and answers.
operations.CreateIndex:
Creates a new Amazon Kendra index. Index creation is an asynchronous operation. To determine if index creation has completed, check the Status field returned from a call to . The Status field is set to ACTIVE when the index is ready to use.

Once the index is active you can index your documents using the operation or using one of the supported data sources.
operations.DeleteIndex: Deletes an existing Amazon Kendra index. An exception is not thrown if the index is already being deleted. While the index is being deleted, the Status field returned by a call to the DescribeIndex operation is set to DELETING.
operations.DescribeDataSource: Gets information about a Amazon Kendra data source.
operations.ListDataSourceSyncJobs: Gets statistics about synchronizing Amazon Kendra with a data source.
operations.ListDataSources: Lists the data sources that you have created.
operations.ListFaqs: Gets a list of FAQ lists associated with an index.
operations.ListIndices: Lists the Amazon Kendra indexes that you have created.
operations.Query:
Searches an active index. Use this API to search your documents using query. The Query operation enables to do faceted search and to filter results based on document attributes.

It also enables you to provide user context that Amazon Kendra uses to enforce document access control in the search results.

Amazon Kendra searches your index for text content and question and answer (FAQ) content. By default the response contains three types of results.

  • Relevant passages

  • Matching FAQs

  • Relevant documents

You can specify that the query return only one type of result using the QueryResultTypeConfig parameter.
operations.StartDataSourceSyncJob: Starts a synchronization job for a data source. If a synchronization job is already in progress, Amazon Kendra returns a ResourceInUseException exception.
operations.StopDataSourceSyncJob: Stops a running synchronization job. You can't stop a scheduled synchronization job.
operations.SubmitFeedback: Enables you to provide feedback to Amazon Kendra to improve the performance of the service.
operations.UpdateDataSource: Updates an existing Amazon Kendra data source.

AccessControlListConfiguration.base: Access Control List files for the documents in a data source.

refs.S3DataSourceConfiguration$AccessControlL: Provides the path to the S3 bucket that contains the user context filtering files for the data source.

AclConfiguration.base: Provides information about the column that should be used for filtering the query response by groups.

refs.DatabaseConfiguration$AclConfiguration: Information about the database column that provides information for user context filtering.

AdditionalResultAttributeValue.base: An attribute returned with a document from a search.

AttributeFilter.base: Provides filtering the query results based on document attributes.

refs.AttributeFilter$NotFilter: Performs a logical NOT operation on all supplied filters.
refs.QueryRequest$AttributeFilter:
Enables filtered searches based on document attributes. You can only provide one attribute filter; however, the AndAllFilters, NotFilter, and OrAllFilters parameters contain a list of other filters.

The AttributeFilter parameter enables you to create a set of filtering rules that a document must satisfy to be included in the query results.

refs.AttributeFilter$AndAllFilters: Performs a logical AND operation on all supplied filters.
refs.AttributeFilter$OrAllFilters: Performs a logical OR operation on all supplied filters.

BatchDeleteDocumentResponseFailedDocumen.base: Provides information about documents that could not be removed from an index by the BatchDeleteDocument operation.

refs.BatchDeleteDocumentResponse$FailedDocume: A list of documents that could not be removed from the index. Each entry contains an error message that indicates why the document couldn't be removed from the index.

BatchPutDocumentResponseFailedDocument.base: Provides information about a document that could not be indexed.

refs.BatchPutDocumentResponse$FailedDocuments:
A list of documents that were not added to the index because the document failed a validation check. Each document contains an error message that indicates why the document couldn't be added to the index.

If there was an error adding a document to an index the error is reported in your AWS CloudWatch log.

refs.Document$Blob: The contents of the document as a base-64 encoded string.

refs.Highlight$TopAnswer: Indicates whether the response is the best response. True if this is the best response; otherwise, false.
refs.Search$Facetable: Indicates that the field can be used to create search facets, a count of results for each value in the field. The default is false .
refs.Search$Searchable: Determines whether the field is used in the search. If the Searchable field is true, you can use relevance tuning to manually tune how Amazon Kendra weights the field in the search. The default is true for string fields and false for number and date fields.
refs.Search$Displayable: Determines whether the field is returned in the query response. The default is true.
refs.SharePointConfiguration$CrawlAttachments: TRUE to include attachments to documents stored in your Microsoft SharePoint site in the index; otherwise, FALSE.

refs.ColumnConfiguration$ChangeDetectingColum: One to five columns that indicate when a document in the database has changed.

ClickFeedback.base: Gathers information about when a particular result was clicked by a user. Your application uses the SubmitFeedback operation to provide click information.

refs.SubmitFeedbackRequest$ClickFeedbackItems: Tells Amazon Kendra that a particular search result link was chosen by the user.

ColumnConfiguration.base: Provides information about how Amazon Kendra should use the columns of a database in an index.

refs.DatabaseConfiguration$ColumnConfiguratio: Information about where the index should get the document information from the database.

refs.AclConfiguration$AllowedGroupsColumnName: A list of groups, separated by semi-colons, that filters a query response based on user context. The document is only returned to users that are in one of the groups specified in the UserContext field of the Query operation.
refs.ColumnConfiguration$DocumentIdColumnName: The column that provides the document's unique identifier.
refs.ColumnConfiguration$DocumentDataColumnNa: The column that contains the contents of the document.
refs.ColumnConfiguration$DocumentTitleColumnN: The column that contains the title of the document.

ConnectionConfiguration.base: Provides the information necessary to connect to a database.

refs.DatabaseConfiguration$ConnectionConfigur: The information necessary to connect to a database.

refs.Document$ContentType: The file type of the document in the Blob field.

DataSourceConfiguration.base: Configuration information for a Amazon Kendra data source.

refs.CreateDataSourceRequest$Configuration: The connector configuration information that is required to access the repository.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$Configuration: Information that describes where the data source is located and how the data source is configured. The specific information in the description depends on the data source provider.

refs.DataSourceToIndexFieldMapping$DateFieldF: The type of data stored in the column or attribute.

refs.DataSourceToIndexFieldMapping$DataSource: The name of the column or attribute in the data source.

refs.CreateDataSourceResponse$Id: A unique identifier for the data source.
refs.DataSourceSummary$Id: The unique identifier for the data source.
refs.DescribeDataSourceRequest$Id: The unique identifier of the data source to describe.
refs.StartDataSourceSyncJobRequest$Id: The identifier of the data source to synchronize.
refs.StopDataSourceSyncJobRequest$Id: The identifier of the data source for which to stop the synchronization jobs.
refs.UpdateDataSourceRequest$Id: The unique identifier of the data source to update.

refs.S3DataSourceConfiguration$InclusionPrefi: A list of S3 prefixes for the documents that should be included in the index.
refs.S3DataSourceConfiguration$ExclusionPatte:
A list of glob patterns for documents that should not be indexed. If a document that matches an inclusion prefix also matches an exclusion pattern, the document is not indexed.

For more information about glob patterns, see glob (programming) in Wikipedia.

refs.CreateDataSourceRequest$Name: A unique name for the data source. A data source name can't be changed without deleting and recreating the data source.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$Name: The name that you gave the data source when it was created.
refs.UpdateDataSourceRequest$Name: The name of the data source to update. The name of the data source can't be updated. To rename a data source you must delete the data source and re-create it.

refs.DataSourceSummary$Status: The status of the data source. When the status is ATIVE the data source is ready to use.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$Status: The current status of the data source. When the status is ACTIVE the data source is ready to use. When the status is FAILED, the ErrorMessage field contains the reason that the data source failed.

DataSourceSummary.base: Summary information for a Amazon Kendra data source. Returned in a call to .

refs.ListDataSourcesResponse$SummaryItems: An array of summary information for one or more data sources.

refs.ListDataSourceSyncJobsResponse$History: A history of synchronization jobs for the data source.

refs.DataSourceSyncJob$Status: The execution status of the synchronization job. When the Status field is set to SUCCEEDED, the synchronization job is done. If the status code is set to FAILED, the ErrorCode and ErrorMessage fields give you the reason for the failure.
refs.ListDataSourceSyncJobsRequest$StatusFilt: When specified, only returns synchronization jobs with the Status field equal to the specified status.

DataSourceToIndexFieldMapping.base: Maps a column or attribute in the data source to an index field. You must first create the fields in the index using the UpdateIndex operation.

refs.ColumnConfiguration$FieldMappings: An array of objects that map database column names to the corresponding fields in an index. You must first create the fields in the index using the UpdateIndex operation.
refs.SharePointConfiguration$FieldMappings: A list of DataSourceToIndexFieldMapping objects that map Microsoft SharePoint attributes to custom fields in the Amazon Kendra index. You must first create the index fields using the operation before you map SharePoint attributes. For more information, see Mapping Data Source Fields.

refs.CreateDataSourceRequest$Type: The type of repository that contains the data source.

DataSourceVpcConfiguration.base: Provides information for connecting to an Amazon VPC.

DatabaseConfiguration.base: Provides the information necessary to connect a database to an index.

refs.DataSourceConfiguration$DatabaseConfigur: Provides information necessary to create a connector for a database.

refs.DatabaseConfiguration$DatabaseEngineType: The type of database engine that runs the database.

refs.ConnectionConfiguration$DatabaseHost: The name of the host for the database. Can be either a string (host.subdomain.domain.tld) or an IPv4 or IPv6 address.

refs.ConnectionConfiguration$DatabaseName: The name of the database containing the document data.

refs.ConnectionConfiguration$DatabasePort: The port that the database uses for connections.

refs.DescribeFaqResponse$Description: The description of the FAQ that you provided when it was created.
refs.UpdateDataSourceRequest$Description: The new description for the data source.

DocumentAttribute.base: A custom attribute value assigned to a document.

refs.AttributeFilter$EqualsTo: Performs an equals operation on two document attributes.
refs.AttributeFilter$ContainsAll: Returns true when a document contains all of the specified document attributes.
refs.AttributeFilter$ContainsAny: Returns true when a document contains any of the specified document attributes.
refs.AttributeFilter$GreaterThan: Performs a greater than operation on two document attributes. Use with a document attribute of type Integer or Long.
refs.AttributeFilter$GreaterThanOrEquals: Performs a greater or equals than operation on two document attributes. Use with a document attribute of type Integer or Long.
refs.AttributeFilter$LessThan: Performs a less than operation on two document attributes. Use with a document attribute of type Integer or Long.
refs.AttributeFilter$LessThanOrEquals: Performs a less than or equals operation on two document attributes. Use with a document attribute of type Integer or Long.

refs.Facet$DocumentAttributeKey: The unique key for the document attribute.
refs.FacetResult$DocumentAttributeKey: The key for the facet values. This is the same as the DocumentAttributeKey provided in the query.

refs.QueryRequest$RequestedDocumentAttributes: An array of document attributes to include in the response. No other document attributes are included in the response. By default all document attributes are included in the response.

refs.Document$Attributes: Custom attributes to apply to the document. Use the custom attributes to provide additional information for searching, to provide facets for refining searches, and to provide additional information in the query response.
refs.QueryResultItem$DocumentAttributes: An array of document attributes for the document that the query result maps to. For example, the document author (Author) or the source URI (SourceUri) of the document.

DocumentAttributeValue.base: The value of a custom document attribute. You can only provide one value for a custom attribute.

refs.DocumentAttributeValueCountPair$Document: The value of the attribute. For example, "HR."

DocumentAttributeValueCountPair.base: Provides the count of documents that match a particular attribute when doing a faceted search.

refs.FacetResult$DocumentAttributeValueCountP: An array of key/value pairs, where the key is the value of the attribute and the count is the number of documents that share the key value.

refs.DocumentMetadataConfiguration$Type: The data type of the index field.

refs.BatchDeleteDocumentResponseFailedDocumen: The identifier of the document that couldn't be removed from the index.
refs.Document$Id: A unique identifier of the document in the index.

refs.BatchDeleteDocumentRequest$DocumentIdLis: One or more identifiers for documents to delete from the index.

refs.BatchPutDocumentRequest$Documents:
One or more documents to add to the index.

Each document is limited to 5 Mb, the total size of the list is limited to 50 Mb.

refs.Relevance$Freshness: Indicates that this field determines how "fresh" a document is. For example, if document 1 was created on November 5, and document 2 was created on October 31, document 1 is "fresher" than document 2. You can only set the Freshness field on one DATE type field. Only applies to DATE fields.

DocumentMetadataConfiguration.base: Specifies the properties of a custom index field.

refs.DescribeIndexResponse$DocumentMetadataCo: Configuration settings for any metadata applied to the documents in the index.

DocumentsMetadataConfiguration.base: Document metadata files that contain information such as the document access control information, source URI, document author, and custom attributes. Each metadata file contains metadata about a single document.

refs.Relevance$Duration:
Specifies the time period that the boost applies to. For example, to make the boost apply to documents with the field value within the last month, you would use "2628000s". Once the field value is beyond the specified range, the effect of the boost drops off. The higher the importance, the faster the effect drops off. If you don't specify a value, the default is 3 months. The value of the field is a numeric string followed by the character "s", for example "86400s" for one day, or "604800s" for one week.

Only applies to DATE fields.

refs.BatchDeleteDocumentResponseFailedDocumen: The error code for why the document couldn't be removed from the index.
refs.BatchPutDocumentResponseFailedDocument$E: The type of error that caused the document to fail to be indexed.
refs.DataSourceSyncJob$ErrorCode: If the Status field is set to FAILED, the ErrorCode field contains a the reason that the synchronization failed.

refs.BatchDeleteDocumentResponseFailedDocumen: An explanation for why the document couldn't be removed from the index.
refs.BatchPutDocumentResponseFailedDocument$E: A description of the reason why the document could not be indexed.
refs.DataSourceSyncJob$ErrorMessage: If the Status field is set to ERROR, the ErrorMessage field contains a description of the error that caused the synchronization to fail.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$ErrorMessage: When the Status field value is FAILED, the ErrorMessage field contains a description of the error that caused the data source to fail.
refs.DescribeFaqResponse$ErrorMessage: If the Status field is FAILED, the ErrorMessage field contains the reason why the FAQ failed.
refs.DescribeIndexResponse$ErrorMessage: When th eStatus field value is FAILED, the ErrorMessage field contains a message that explains why.

refs.QueryRequest$Facets: An array of documents attributes. Amazon Kendra returns a count for each attribute key specified. You can use this information to help narrow the search for your user.

FacetResult.base: The facet values for the documents in the response.

refs.QueryResult$FacetResults: Contains the facet results. A FacetResult contains the counts for each attribute key that was specified in the Facets input parameter.

refs.DeleteFaqRequest$Id: The identifier of the FAQ to remove.

refs.CreateFaqRequest$Name: The name that should be associated with the FAQ.
refs.DescribeFaqResponse$Name: The name that you gave the FAQ when it was created.
refs.FaqSummary$Name: The name that you assigned the FAQ when you created or updated the FAQ.

FaqStatistics.base: Provides statistical information about the FAQ questions and answers contained in an index.

refs.IndexStatistics$FaqStatistics: The number of question and answer topics in the index.

refs.DescribeFaqResponse$Status: The status of the FAQ. It is ready to use when the status is ACTIVE.
refs.FaqSummary$Status: The current status of the FAQ. When the status is ACTIVE the FAQ is ready for use.

FaqSummary.base: Provides information about a frequently asked questions and answer contained in an index.

refs.ListFaqsResponse$FaqSummaryItems: information about the FAQs associated with the specified index.

Highlight.base: Provides information that you can use to highlight a search result so that your users can quickly identify terms in the response.

refs.TextWithHighlights$Highlights: The beginning and end of the text that should be highlighted.

refs.Relevance$Importance: The relative importance of the field in the search. Larger numbers provide more of a boost than smaller numbers.

IndexConfigurationSummary.base: A summary of information about an index.

refs.ListIndicesResponse$IndexConfigurationSu: An array of summary information for one or more indexes.

refs.DataSourceToIndexFieldMapping$IndexField: The name of the field in the index.

refs.BatchDeleteDocumentRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the documents to delete.
refs.BatchPutDocumentRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index to add the documents to. You need to create the index first using the CreateIndex operation.
refs.CreateDataSourceRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that should be associated with this data source.
refs.CreateFaqRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the FAQ.
refs.CreateIndexResponse$Id: The unique identifier of the index. Use this identifier when you query an index, set up a data source, or index a document.
refs.DeleteFaqRequest$IndexId: The index to remove the FAQ from.
refs.DeleteIndexRequest$Id: The identifier of the index to delete.
refs.DescribeDataSourceRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the data source.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the data source.
refs.DescribeFaqRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the FAQ.
refs.DescribeFaqResponse$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the FAQ.
refs.DescribeIndexRequest$Id: The name of the index to describe.
refs.IndexConfigurationSummary$Id: A unique identifier for the index. Use this to identify the index when you are using operations such as Query, DescribeIndex, UpdateIndex, and DeleteIndex.
refs.ListDataSourceSyncJobsRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the data source.
refs.ListDataSourcesRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the data source.
refs.ListFaqsRequest$IndexId: The index that contains the FAQ lists.
refs.QueryRequest$IndexId: The unique identifier of the index to search. The identifier is returned in the response from the operation.
refs.StartDataSourceSyncJobRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the data source.
refs.StopDataSourceSyncJobRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the data source.
refs.SubmitFeedbackRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that was queried.
refs.UpdateDataSourceRequest$IndexId: The identifier of the index that contains the data source to update.
refs.UpdateIndexRequest$Id: The identifier of the index to update.

refs.UpdateIndexRequest$Name: The name of the index to update.

IndexStatistics.base: Provides information about the number of documents and the number of questions and answers in an index.

refs.DescribeIndexResponse$IndexStatistics: Provides information about the number of FAQ questions and answers and the number of text documents indexed.

refs.DescribeIndexResponse$Status: The current status of the index. When the value is ACTIVE, the index is ready for use. If the Status field value is FAILED, the ErrorMessage field contains a message that explains why.
refs.IndexConfigurationSummary$Status: The current status of the index. When the status is ACTIVE, the index is ready to search.

refs.FaqStatistics$IndexedQuestionAnswersCoun: The total number of FAQ questions and answers contained in the index.

refs.DocumentAttributeValueCountPair$Count: The number of documents in the response that have the attribute value for the key.
refs.Highlight$BeginOffset: The zero-based location in the response string where the highlight starts.
refs.Highlight$EndOffset: The zero-based location in the response string where the highlight ends.
refs.QueryRequest$PageNumber: Query results are returned in pages the size of the PageSize parameter. By default, Amazon Kendra returns the first page of results. Use this parameter to get result pages after the first one.
refs.QueryRequest$PageSize: Sets the number of results that are returned in each page of results. The default page size is 100.
refs.QueryResult$TotalNumberOfResults: The number of items returned by the search. Use this to determine when you have requested the last set of results.

refs.ListDataSourceSyncJobsRequest$MaxResults: The maximum number of synchronization jobs to return in the response. If there are fewer results in the list, this response contains only the actual results.

refs.ListDataSourcesRequest$MaxResults: The maximum number of data sources to return.

refs.ListFaqsRequest$MaxResults: The maximum number of FAQs to return in the response. If there are fewer results in the list, this response contains only the actual results.

refs.ListIndicesRequest$MaxResults: The maximum number of data sources to return.

refs.ListDataSourceSyncJobsRequest$NextToken: If the result of the previous request to GetDataSourceSyncJobHistory was truncated, include the NextToken to fetch the next set of jobs.
refs.ListDataSourceSyncJobsResponse$NextToken: The GetDataSourceSyncJobHistory operation returns a page of vocabularies at a time. The maximum size of the page is set by the MaxResults parameter. If there are more jobs in the list than the page size, Amazon Kendra returns the NextPage token. Include the token in the next request to the GetDataSourceSyncJobHistory operation to return in the next page of jobs.
refs.ListDataSourcesRequest$NextToken: If the previous response was incomplete (because there is more data to retrieve), Amazon Kendra returns a pagination token in the response. You can use this pagination token to retrieve the next set of data sources (DataSourceSummaryItems).
refs.ListDataSourcesResponse$NextToken: If the response is truncated, Amazon Kendra returns this token that you can use in the subsequent request to retrieve the next set of data sources.
refs.ListFaqsRequest$NextToken: If the result of the previous request to ListFaqs was truncated, include the NextToken to fetch the next set of FAQs.
refs.ListFaqsResponse$NextToken: The ListFaqs operation returns a page of FAQs at a time. The maximum size of the page is set by the MaxResults parameter. If there are more jobs in the list than the page size, Amazon Kendra returns the NextPage token. Include the token in the next request to the ListFaqs operation to return the next page of FAQs.
refs.ListIndicesRequest$NextToken: If the previous response was incomplete (because there is more data to retrieve), Amazon Kendra returns a pagination token in the response. You can use this pagination token to retrieve the next set of indexes (DataSourceSummaryItems).
refs.ListIndicesResponse$NextToken: If the response is truncated, Amazon Kendra returns this token that you can use in the subsequent request to retrieve the next set of indexes.

refs.Relevance$RankOrder:
Determines how values should be interpreted.

When the RankOrder field is ASCENDING, higher numbers are better. For example, a document with a rating score of 10 is higher ranking than a document with a rating score of 1.

When the RankOrder field is DESCENDING, lower numbers are better. For example, in a task tracking application, a priority 1 task is more important than a priority 5 task.

Only applies to LONG and DOUBLE fields.

Principal.base: Provides user and group information for document access filtering.

refs.Document$AccessControlList: Information to use for user context filtering.

refs.Principal$Name: The name of the user or group.

refs.QueryResult$QueryId: The unique identifier for the search. You use QueryId to identify the search when using the feedback API.
refs.SubmitFeedbackRequest$QueryId: The identifier of the specific query for which you are submitting feedback. The query ID is returned in the response to the operation.

QueryResultItem.base:
A single query result.

A query result contains information about a document returned by the query. This includes the original location of the document, a list of attributes assigned to the document, and relevant text from the document that satisfies the query.

refs.QueryRequest$QueryResultTypeFilter: Sets the type of query. Only results for the specified query type are returned.

refs.Principal$Access: Whether to allow or deny access to the principal.

Relevance.base: Provides information for manually tuning the relevance of a field in a search. When a query includes terms that match the field, the results are given a boost in the response based on these tuning parameters.

refs.DocumentMetadataConfiguration$Relevance: Provides manual tuning parameters to determine how the field affects the search results.

RelevanceFeedback.base: Provides feedback on how relevant a document is to a search. Your application uses the SubmitFeedback operation to provide relevance information.

refs.SubmitFeedbackRequest$RelevanceFeedbackI: Provides Amazon Kendra with relevant or not relevant feedback for whether a particular item was relevant to the search.

refs.RelevanceFeedback$RelevanceValue: Whether to document was relevant or not relevant to the search.

refs.ClickFeedback$ResultId: The unique identifier of the search result that was clicked.
refs.QueryResultItem$Id: The unique identifier for the query result.
refs.RelevanceFeedback$ResultId: The unique identifier of the search result that the user provided relevance feedback for.

refs.BatchPutDocumentRequest$RoleArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a role that is allowed to run the BatchPutDocument operation. For more information, see IAM Roles for Amazon Kendra.
refs.CreateDataSourceRequest$RoleArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a role with permission to access the data source. For more information, see IAM Roles for Amazon Kendra.
refs.CreateFaqRequest$RoleArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a role with permission to access the S3 bucket that contains the FAQs. For more information, see IAM Roles for Amazon Kendra.
refs.CreateIndexRequest$RoleArn: An IAM role that gives Amazon Kendra permissions to access your Amazon CloudWatch logs and metrics. This is also the role used when you use the BatchPutDocument operation to index documents from an Amazon S3 bucket.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$RoleArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role that enables the data source to access its resources.
refs.DescribeFaqResponse$RoleArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role that provides access to the S3 bucket containing the input files for the FAQ.
refs.DescribeIndexResponse$RoleArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that gives Amazon Kendra permission to write to your Amazon Cloudwatch logs.
refs.UpdateDataSourceRequest$RoleArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the new role to use when the data source is accessing resources on your behalf.
refs.UpdateIndexRequest$RoleArn: A new IAM role that gives Amazon Kendra permission to access your Amazon CloudWatch logs.

refs.S3DataSourceConfiguration$BucketName: The name of the bucket that contains the documents.
refs.S3Path$Bucket: The name of the S3 bucket that contains the file.

S3DataSourceConfiguration.base: Provides configuration information for a data source to index documents in an Amazon S3 bucket.

refs.DataSourceConfiguration$S3Configuration: Provides information to create a connector for a document repository in an Amazon S3 bucket.

refs.AccessControlListConfiguration$KeyPath: Path to the AWS S3 bucket that contains the ACL files.
refs.DocumentsMetadataConfiguration$S3Prefix: A prefix used to filter metadata configuration files in the AWS S3 bucket. The S3 bucket might contain multiple metadata files. Use S3Prefix to include only the desired metadata files.

S3Path.base: Information required to find a specific file in an Amazon S3 bucket.

refs.CreateFaqRequest$S3Path: The S3 location of the FAQ input data.

refs.CreateDataSourceRequest$Schedule: Sets the frequency that Amazon Kendra will check the documents in your repository and update the index. If you don't set a schedule Amazon Kendra will not periodically update the index. You can call the StartDataSourceSyncJob operation to update the index.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$Schedule: The schedule that Amazon Kendra will update the data source.
refs.UpdateDataSourceRequest$Schedule: The new update schedule for the data source.

Search.base: Provides information about how a custom index field is used during a search.

refs.DocumentMetadataConfiguration$Search: Provides information about how the field is used during a search.

refs.ConnectionConfiguration$SecretArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of credentials stored in AWS Secrets Manager. The credentials should be a user/password pair. For more information, see Using a Database Data Source. For more information about AWS Secrets Manager, see What Is AWS Secrets Manager in the AWS Secrets Manager user guide.
refs.SharePointConfiguration$SecretArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of credentials stored in AWS Secrets Manager. The credentials should be a user/password pair. For more information, see Using a Microsoft SharePoint Data Source. For more information about AWS Secrets Manager, see What Is AWS Secrets Manager in the AWS Secrets Manager user guide.

refs.DataSourceVpcConfiguration$SecurityGroup: A list of identifiers of security groups within your Amazon VPC. The security groups should enable Amazon Kendra to connect to the data source.

ServerSideEncryptionConfiguration.base: Provides the identifier of the KMS key used to encrypt data indexed by Amazon Kendra.

refs.CreateIndexRequest$ServerSideEncryptionC: The identifier of the KMS key to use to encrypt data indexed by Amazon Kendra.
refs.DescribeIndexResponse$ServerSideEncrypti: The identifier of the KMS key used to encrypt your data.

SharePointConfiguration.base: Provides configuration information for connecting to a Microsoft SharePoint data source.

refs.DataSourceConfiguration$SharePointConfig: Provides information necessary to create a connector for a Microsoft SharePoint site.

refs.SharePointConfiguration$Urls: The URLs of the Microsoft SharePoint site that contains the documents that should be indexed.

refs.SharePointConfiguration$SharePointVersio: The version of Microsoft SharePoint that you are using as a data source.

refs.DataSourceSyncJob$ExecutionId: A unique identifier for the synchronization job.
refs.DataSourceSyncJob$DataSourceErrorCode: If the reason that the synchronization failed is due to an error with the underlying data source, this field contains a code that identifies the error.
refs.TextWithHighlights$Text: The text to display to the user.

refs.DataSourceVpcConfiguration$SubnetIds: A list of identifiers for subnets within your Amazon VPC. The subnets should be able to connect to each other in the VPC, and they should have outgoing access to the Internet through a NAT device.

refs.ConnectionConfiguration$TableName: The name of the table that contains the document data.

TextDocumentStatistics.base: Provides information about text documents indexed in an index.

TextWithHighlights.base: Provides text and information about where to highlight the text.

refs.AdditionalResultAttributeValue$TextWithH: The text associated with the attribute and information about the highlight to apply to the text.
refs.QueryResultItem$DocumentTitle: The title of the document. Contains the text of the title and information for highlighting the relevant terms in the title.
refs.QueryResultItem$DocumentExcerpt: An extract of the text in the document. Contains information about highlighting the relevant terms in the excerpt.

refs.ListDataSourceSyncJobsRequest$StartTimeF: When specified, the synchronization jobs returned in the list are limited to jobs between the specified dates.

refs.ClickFeedback$ClickTime: The Unix timestamp of the data and time that the result was clicked.
refs.DataSourceSummary$CreatedAt: The UNIX datetime that the data source was created.
refs.DataSourceSummary$UpdatedAt: The UNIX datetime that the data source was lasted updated.
refs.DataSourceSyncJob$StartTime: The UNIX datetime that the synchronization job was started.
refs.DataSourceSyncJob$EndTime: The UNIX datetime that the synchronization job was completed.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$CreatedAt: The Unix timestamp of when the data source was created.
refs.DescribeDataSourceResponse$UpdatedAt: The Unix timestamp of when the data source was last updated.
refs.DescribeFaqResponse$CreatedAt: The date and time that the FAQ was created.
refs.DescribeFaqResponse$UpdatedAt: The date and time that the FAQ was last updated.
refs.DescribeIndexResponse$CreatedAt: The Unix datetime that the index was created.
refs.DescribeIndexResponse$UpdatedAt: The Unix datetime that the index was last updated.
refs.DocumentAttributeValue$DateValue: A date value expressed as seconds from the Unix epoch.
refs.FaqSummary$CreatedAt: The UNIX datetime that the FAQ was added to the index.
refs.FaqSummary$UpdatedAt: The UNIX datetime that the FAQ was last updated.
refs.IndexConfigurationSummary$CreatedAt: The Unix timestamp when the index was created.
refs.IndexConfigurationSummary$UpdatedAt: The Unix timestamp when the index was last updated by the UpdateIndex operation.
refs.TimeRange$StartTime: The UNIX datetime of the beginning of the time range.
refs.TimeRange$EndTime: The UNIX datetime of the end of the time range.

refs.QueryResultItem$DocumentURI: The URI of the original location of the document.

refs.Relevance$ValueImportanceMap:
A list of values that should be given a different boost when they appear in the result list. For example, if you are boosting a field called "department," query terms that match the department field are boosted in the result. However, you can add entries from the department field to boost documents with those values higher.

For example, you can add entries to the map with names of departments. If you add "HR",5 and "Legal",3 those departments are given special attention when they appear in the metadata of a document. When those terms appear they are given the specified importance instead of the regular importance for the boost.
